article_title: Stephen Blackwood: ObamaCare and My Mother's Cancer Medicine
article_text: When my mother was diagnosed with carcinoid cancer in 2005, when she was 49, it came as a lightning shock. Her mother, at 76, had yet to go gray, and her mother's mother, at 95, was still playing bingo in her nursing home. My mother had always been, despite her diminutive frame, a titanic and irrepressible force of vitality and love. She had given birth to me and my nine younger siblings, and juggled kids, home and my father's medical practice with humor and grace for three decades. She swam three times a week in the early...

twitter.description: In The Wall Street Journal, Stephen Blackwood writes that thanks to ObamaCare, his mother lost a health insurance policy that covered her cancer treatments, and now has a more expensive policy that does not.
twitter.title: Stephen Blackwood: ObamaCare and My Mother's Cancer Medicine

image.alt: ObamaCare and My Mother's Cancer Medicine

article_summary:
When my mother was diagnosed with carcinoid cancer in 2005, when she was 49, it came as a lightning shock.
She had given birth to me and my nine younger siblings, and juggled kids, home and my father's medical practice with humor and grace for three decades.
Her mother, at 76, had yet to go gray, and her mother's mother, at 95, was still playing bingo in her nursing home.
She swam three times a week in the early...
My mother had always been, despite her diminutive frame, a titanic and irrepressible force of vitality and love.
